abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey satisfactory project
            outcomes, a highly likely sustainability, and high
            institutional development impacts, in addition to
            satisfactory performances, both by the Bank and Borrower.
            Lessons concerning project design, suggest community
            forestry as an effective instrument for sustainable rural
            development, namely, this model encompassed the development
            of social capital (based on traditional forms of
            governance), a minimum base of natural capital (forest
            resources with commercial value), and, the development of
            technical and administrative capacity (human capital) of the
            producers. Hence, a regional vision on the use of natural
            resources should be fostered, seeking to achieve an economic
            scale, through greater integration of productive chains.
            However, the development of community forestry have not been
            linear, and the cause of structural limitation to access to
            markets, and lay natural capital, needs to be addressed, so
            as to access investment funds. While project design was not
            focused on communities engaged in land conflicts, (rather
            excluding significant numbers of communities, and depriving
            such communities from incentives to find a way out of
            conflict), the opposing decision however, could create a gap
            between communities engaged in conflict, and those that are
            not. Moreover, the project did not directly benefit the
            people living in, or near communities, that are not members,
            nor own the resources, or share in the decisions, neither in
            the form of employment and enhanced public services. This
            issue also raises questions about exacerbating gaps between
            richer and poorer, and leaving significant numbers of poor
            behind in the development process. Likewise, the project
            design did not directly assist women, or help them achieve
            an active role in community decision making. Project
            implementation lessons strongly support the frequent
            interventions of promoters, and technical support in forums,
            and other regional fora in community assemblies, including
            individual efforts to disseminate, and analyze options on
            performance of productive initiatives, which provided
            invaluable benefits in community strengthening. The
            viability of the community forestry enterprises, depend on
            their capacity to compete in global markets. However, the
            experience with private and parastatal companies has led to
            many communities with an understandable reluctance to engage
            in partnerships with the private sector. Hopefully, as
            communities strengthen their capacity for governance and
            technical skills, it will be possible to overcome this fear
            and establish linkages to private sector strategies, and to
            establish commercial alliances with productive agents,
            allowing access to new local, and regional markets.
